required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Gastric Insufflation During Positive Pressure Ventilation
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of the Peak Inspiratory Pressure and Facial Mask Holding Techniques on the Gastric Insufflation During Positive Pressure Ventilation With Facemask in Obese Adults

brief_summary.textblock: Effect of peak inspiratory pressure on the gastric insufflation is evaluated using ultrasonography during face mask ventilation in obese adults. Effect of facial mask holding techniques on the gastric insufflation is also evaluated.

primary_outcome.measure: Presence of gastric insufflation in the epigastric region
primary_outcome.description: Under ultrasound, air signal is assessed in the epigastric region

secondary_outcome.measure: Cross-sectional area of the antral cross-sectional area
secondary_outcome.description: During ultrasound examination, anterior-posterior diameter and cranio-caudal diameter of the antrum are measured. Cross-sectional area of the gastric antrum is calculated as follows; (AP × CC × π)/4 (AP=antero-posterior diameter and CC=cranio-caudal diameter).

secondary_outcome.measure: Presence of gastric insufflation in the upper esophageal region
secondary_outcome.description: Under ultrasound, air signal is assessed in the upper esophageal region.
Expiratory tidal volumes displayed on the monitor of the anesthesia machine are recorded.

arm_group.arm_group_label: C-E Mask ventilation under PIP 10 cmH2O
arm_group.description: Two-handed C-E technique is performed during face mask ventilation using a mechanical ventilator with a peak inspiratory pressure of 10 cmH2O.

arm_group.arm_group_label: C-E Mask ventilation under PIP 15 cmH2O
arm_group.description: Two-handed C-E technique is performed during face mask ventilation using a mechanical ventilator with a peak inspiratory pressure of 15 cmH2O.

arm_group.arm_group_label: C-E Mask ventilation under PIP 20 cmH2O
arm_group.description: Two-handed C-E technique is performed during face mask ventilation using a mechanical ventilator with a peak inspiratory pressure of 20 cmH2O.

arm_group.arm_group_label: V-E Mask ventilation under PIP 10 cmH2O
arm_group.description: Two-handed V-E technique is performed during face mask ventilation using a mechanical ventilator with a peak inspiratory pressure of 10 cmH2O.

arm_group.arm_group_label: V-E Mask ventilation under PIP 15 cmH2O
arm_group.description: Two-handed V-E technique is performed during face mask ventilation using a mechanical ventilator with a peak inspiratory pressure of 15 cmH2O.

arm_group.arm_group_label: V-E Mask ventilation under PIP 20 cmH2O
arm_group.description: Two-handed V-E technique is performed during face mask ventilation using a mechanical ventilator with a peak inspiratory pressure of 20 cmH2O.

intervention.intervention_name: ultrasound examination of air insufflation in the upper esophageal region and stomach
intervention.description: Presence of air insufflation is assessed using ultrasound in the upper esophageal region and stomach during face mask ventilation
intervention.arm_group_label: C-E Mask ventilation under PIP 10 cmH2O

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients with body mass index ≥ 30 kg/m2 who are scheduled for general anesthesia
Exclusion Criteria:
- Risk of delayed gastric emptying or gastroesophageal reflux (gastroesophageal reflux disease, achalasia, history of stomach surgery, gastrointestinal obstruction, uncontrolled DM)
- Pregnancy
- Known or predicted difficult airway
